message: I have the same question, any help?
story: Kareem Elansary shared a link to the group: Egyptian Geeks.
name: Create Package in Bower Using bitbucket repository
caption: stackoverflow.com
description: I am trying to register a package using bower register <name> https://git@bitbucket.org.. but bower is not creating a new package and throwing error as it is not a valid url and URl has to st...

data.message:
This is one of the earliest issues reported on bower and it seem like they fixed it: https://github.com/bower/registry/issues/4
What's the error you are getting?
Trying to help man give me more info instead of a sad face :(
not fixed ... did you tried this before ? to register a bower package from a bitbucket ?
Didn't register private packages before actually. Can you move that to github? Or it is gonna be a private package?
This pull request didn't reslove it ? https://github.com/bower/registry/pull/78
ok, so they make a decision not to register any private repo as a package .. it should be public. either on github or bitbucket

It makes sense to register only public repositories into the public registry.

Depending on "Why" you want to do this, you can choose from the following options

- Open the repo for public if possible. Delete it quick if the reason for private is testing with no rubbish behind you.

- Have a different repository just for the bower distribution artefacts. A lot of even public OSS projects do that. You can push to it manually or set it up in your build process.

- Instead of a registry, just tell people to install the dependency from the git URL you have. Yes, bower can install dependencies from HTTPS private git repositories. I have done it before. I just stick the URL in the bower.json file and run bower install You can even specify branch name to pull from, or a specific tag.

- You can have a private bower registry and get other people in your team to add manually. I could find a few articles about it with a simple search. I don't see much value of doing that over just installing from the git URL though.
